prompt: In standard deontic logic, O(p) → P(p) means:
options: If something is possible, it's obligatory
If something is obligatory, it's permitted
If something is permitted, it's obligatory
hint: 'Ought implies can' - you can't be obligated to do what's not allowed.
explanation: O(p) → P(p) captures the intuition that obligations entail permissions. If you're obligated to do something, it must at least be permitted. You can't be required to do what's forbidden - that would be an incoherent normative system.
visual_concept: If you MUST pay taxes, then paying taxes must be ALLOWED. Obligation is a stronger requirement than mere permission.
